xxl.core.io.propertyList.json

Class JSONPrinter

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.io.propertyList.PropertyListPrinter
      • xxl.core.io.propertyList.json.JSONPrinter

  • public class JSONPrinter
extends PropertyListPrinter
    The JSONPrinter is a class which takes a PropertyList instance and prints it to a given OutputStream in a format of a JSON file.

    Example In the example a property list is creates which contains a (simple) table dump of a student database table. At first the table name "Students" is set. After this two tuples of students where added. Each has two attributes which are ID and the students name. Finally the property list is printed with a JSONPrinter 
     PropertyList myTable = new PropertyList();
 myTable.add(new Property("Table", "Students"));
 
 PropertyList myTuple1 = new PropertyList();
 myTuple1.add(new Property("ID", 202031));
 myTuple1.add(new Property("Name", "Mustermann"));
 myTuple1.add(new Property("Subjects", new Object[] { "Maths", "Physics" }));
 
 PropertyList myTuple2 = new PropertyList();
 myTuple2.add(new Property("ID", 405066));
 myTuple2.add(new Property("Name", "Musterfrau"));
 myTuple2.add(new Property("Subjects", new Object[] { "English", "Geography" }));
 
 
 myTable.add(new Property("Tuple1", myTuple1));
 myTable.add(new Property("Tuple2", myTuple2));
 
 JSONPrinter printer = new JSONPrinter(myTable);
 printer.print(System.out);
    This produces the following output on the console: 
     { 
  "Table": "Students"
  "Tuple1": { 
    "ID": 202031
    "Name": "Mustermann"
    "Subjects": [ "Maths", "Physics" ]
  }
  "Tuple2": { 
    "ID": 405066
    "Name": "Musterfrau"
    "Subjects": [ "English", "Geography" ]
  }
 }
    Another more elegant way to store multiple instances of an object, like the tuples in the example above, is to add a property which contains a array of property lists. Those nested property lists models the object. In the previous example replace 
     myTable.add(new Property("Tuple1", myTuple1));
 myTable.add(new Property("Tuple2", myTuple2));
     with 
     Object[] propertyListArray = new Object[] { myTuple1, myTuple2 };
 myTable.add(new Property("Tuples", propertyListArray));
    The output result is 
     {
  "Table": "Students"
  "Tuples": [ {
      "ID": 202031
      "Name": "Mustermann"
      "Subjects": [ "Maths", "Physics" ]
    }, {
      "ID": 405066
      "Name": "Musterfrau"
      "Subjects": [ "English", "Geography" ]
    } ]
 }
    By default the printer adds automatically white spaces, tabs and line breaks. If you want to disable at least one of this features use print(OutputStream, int). Note: If you want to set a value assignment to null just leave the value out and use Property.Property(String) constructor, e.g. new Property("ThisIsNull") which leads to the JSON output "ThisIsNull": null.

    Remark: The printer supports the following primitive data types (or wrapper) for
    • String
    • java.sql.Date
    • java.sql.Time
    • java.sql.Timestamp
    • Integer
    • Boolean
    • Byte
    • Double
    • Float
    • Long
    • Short
    or an array of Object which also contains the data types noted above. Also an empty Object[] is possible just as nested ones.

    If you insert a value which does not match the types above, data type it will be discarded and printed as null.
    See Also:
    a collection of Properties, a single item for a PropertyList, the base class for all PropertyListPrinters

    • Constructor Detail

      • JSONPrinter

        public JSONPrinter(PropertyList propertyList)
        Constructs a new instance of JSONPrinter to a given instance of PropertyList. Use print(OutputStream) to print the content of the property list to several output streams.
        Parameters:
        propertyList - The property list which should be printed in JSON format

    • Method Detail

      • print

        public final void print(OutputStream output)
                 throws IOException
        Prints the given PropertyList to the output.
        Specified by:
        print in class PropertyListPrinter
        Parameters:
        output - Output stream
        Throws:
        IOException - If it fails to write into output stream
        See Also:
        for format options

      • print

        public final void print(OutputStream output,
                        int printerOptions)
                 throws IOException
        Prints the given PropertyList to the output. By default the printer adds automatically white spaces, tabs and line breaks. This method expects restrictions to this behavior. These are
        • NO_LINEBREAKS
        • NO_TABS
        • NO_WHITESPACES
        Use logical or to combine this features.

        Example This code disables any extensions that are only for the better human readability. 
         import static JSONPrinter.*;
 
 printer.print(System.out, NO_LINEBREAKS | NO_TABS | NO_WHITESPACES)
        Parameters:
        output - Output stream
        printerOptions - A combination of NO_LINEBREAKS, NO_TABS, NO_WHITESPACES or zero
        Throws:
        IOException - If it fails to write into output stream
